attributes.title: 1. Physical Stock Take
attributes.description:
After stock reconciliation it was confirmed that physical stock quantities for most stock items either matched or showed minimal variance when compared to the book balance, except for the following stock items which recorded significant variance: -

v  Packing Materials had a cumulative positive variance of 3,939 pieces.

v  Bread stock had a negative variation of 75 loaves.

v  Crates had a short fall of 10 crates; the short fall was recovered from the responsible workers.
attributes.recommendation: The branch management needs to strengthen over controls for poly bags , crates and bread in order to reduce the variation  observed.
attributes.effect: Zero and minimal stock variations is an indication of strong stock control. However, weakens was noted on crates controls as evidence by the significant variation.

value:
·  Crates variance :- The variation was due to a pending deduction that had not been raised.

·  Bread short fall :- The variance was minimal however, we will strengthen bread controls to further reduce the variation. 

·      Poly Bags variance :- The variation was high due to an overstatement of poly bag damages. We have addressed this by requiring supervisors to record the actual damages on a per-shift basis.

• The crates were recovered from the cuprite.

  • Bread variance was within the set targe.

  • We will make a follow-on shift wise recording of the poly bags damages to ensure their record actual figures.

In prior audit date 16th April 2025 found that Bread stock had variance of -326 loaves, White flour had variance of +49.999 kg, Yeast had a variance of +6.997 sachets and Utto  had a variance of +0.736 Litres.
Previous

A physical stock take was conducted on 4th June 2025 to assess the accuracy of the stock records by comparing the physical stock count against the book balance.Internal audit team together with branch team  conducted a physical stock take on 4th June 2025.

The physical stock count revealed some variances, mainly in crates, bread, and poly bags. These variances have been addressed by the branch management.  Overall, controls are in place but should be further improved to aid in minimizing future variances.
Operations/Production Department
The aim was to assess whether the physical stock counted matched with the book balance and whether the internal controls put in place were effective and working properly.

attributes.title: 2. Bread Weight
attributes.description: Results from the sample indicated instances of underweight across all the varieties tested, which indicated a widespread issue in weight control during production. The table below illustrates the findings: -
attributes.recommendation: Bread weight control should be enhanced throughout the production process from dividing area to the packing section to ensure that all loaves packed meet the required standard weight.
attributes.effect: Packing underweights is an indication of noncompliance to weight standards and this could expose the company to heavy penalties if caught by the weight and measures officials and could cause reputation risk.

value: Bread weight controls will be strengthen to ensure all bread meets the standard weight.

Compared to the previous audit findings, there is an improvement; however, we will further strengthen controls over bread weight from the dividing area to the packing area to help ensure that bread sent to the market meets the correct weight specification.
In prior audit sampled bread underweight were noted across all varieties except 1500g bread.
Previous
A sample of bread produced, packed in the branch and ready to be distributed in market were randomly selected and weighed.
The branch did not comply with bread weight controls, indicating that controls are not sufficiently strong. Branch needs to strengthen bread controls to ensure weight compliance.
Operations/Production Department
The aim was to check whether bread sent to the market was of the minimum weight of 200g, 400g, 600g. 800g and 1,5kg as set by KEBS.

attributes.title: 3. Bread Damages
attributes.description:
The audit sampled period was from 1st May 2025 to  3rd June 2025. The findings were as follows: -

v  Production damage was averaging at 0.22% of the production damage which was above the set limit

v  Market damage stood at 0.66% of the total sales.

Table 1 Analysis of Production Damage

Table 2 Analysis of Market Damages
attributes.recommendation:
Branch need to tighten production controls to help ensure that bread produced is of high quality thereby reducing  level of the damages.

Market damages were kept under control  and the branch should maintain this trend.
attributes.effect: Production damages and market damages surpassed the set limits. This resulted in cumulative revenue loss of Ksh. 15,396.50

value:
Production damages were slightly above the allowable percentage, however, we will closely monitor the production process to minimize these damages while maintaining high product quality to also reduce market-related damages.

Market damages was within the recommended level. Efforts will be made to sustain these levels through continued adherence to quality standards and handling procedures.

The production damages rate slightly above the set target, but we will try to reduce to the required rate.

Market damages are within the range and we will try to maintain the trend.
During the prior audit it was noted that production damage was 0.24 % of the total production while market damages were 0.33% of the total sales.
Previous
An analysis of production and market damage was calculated.
From the analysis bread damages exceeded the set limit and this indicates that branch was not following up the production procedures.
Operations/Production Department
The Production and market damages were analysed to establish whether they were within the set limit of 0.20% and 0.50% respectively.

attributes.title: 4. Bread damages Sent to ingredients department.
attributes.description:
The reconciliation revealed a minimal variance between the total damages recorded at the branch level and those reported as received by the ingredients department. The total branch level damages amounted to 5,126,50 loaves, whereas the total sent to ingredients department was 5,075.75 loaves, resulting in a negative variance of -50.75 loaves.

Below is a summary of the findings:
attributes.recommendation: Enhance control for damage balance management and maintenance of accurate figures in the branch book records to ensure minimal to nil variations in balances recorded.
attributes.effect: The variance noted was minimal indicating  that controls were strong.

value: The variance observed between the damage sent to ingredients and the damages recorded was primarily attributed to moisture loss
The variance noted was due to moisture loss.
In the prior audit physical damages weighed compared to Manager’s records had a variance of +30.10kg equivalent to 75.25 loaves worth Kes. 3,988.25.
Previous
A reconciliation exercise was carried out to verify the accuracy of bread damage quantities sent to the ingredients department.
The controls for recording and sending bread damages were strong and operating effectively.
Operations/Production Department

The objective was to determine whether the quantities sent to ingredients department corresponded with damages captured in the SAP systems as production damages, market damages, oven damages, bread deductions, and supermarket return. The audit covered the period from 1st May 2025 to 3rd June 2025.

attributes.title: 5. Mixing chart Analysis.
attributes.description:
Below is a summary of the findings.

v  Utto consumption stood at 100 %.

v  The average yield was 192.73 loaves per bag which was within the acceptable limit.

v  Average production was 147.79 bags per day, which is 82.11% of the daily target of 180 bags.

v  No remix was recorded over the audited period.

v  The quantities of bread recorded in the mixing chart summary matched accurately with the figures transferred to the cash flow during the audit period.

The table shows the summary findings of the mixing chart
attributes.recommendation: The branch should strive to ensure that they attain their production target by boosting sales
attributes.effect:
The branch’s average production fell below the set daily target, indicating underutilization of production capacity.

While other process controls (e.g., yield and utto usage) were well maintained, the gap in output performance may affect revenue and overall efficiency.

value: The production target was affected by low sales, as we produce as per the sales demand this helps to control balance. Additionally, production was further impacted by power outages.
The production target was affected by low sales, as we produce in accordance with sales demand
During the prior audit, it was noted that, Average production was 145.59 bags per day, which is 81% of the daily target of 180 bags. Yield achieved during the period was 192.74.
Previous
An analysis of mixing chart and mixing chart summary was conducted for the period 1st May 2025 to 3rd May 2025.
Production procedures were found to be followed to the letter, in full compliance with established guidelines.
Operations/Production Department
The aim was to assess whether raw materials consumption was in line with the Bill of materials (BOM) and whether set yield and quality standards were met.

attributes.title: 6.	Cash Count Analysis.
attributes.description:
The total cash physically counted was Ksh.3,287, which reconciled with the expected cash balance.

There was one pending IOU amounting to Ksh 12,000.00 for the recovery of vehicle KTWC 683X, which was involved in an accident.

At the time of the check, NSSF or SHA remittances amounted to Ksh. 8,950.00
attributes.recommendation: The branch should continue to advocate for good cash asset controls.
attributes.effect: The cash office is adequately managed thus the cash at the branch is adequately safeguarded.

value: Cash was well controlled.
The cash controls in the place were strong and effective and the cashier his encouraged to continue adhering to these procedures.
In a prior audit report, all the cash was well accounted for.
Previous
A spot check was conducted at the branch cash office on 7th May 2025.
The cash controls in place were found to be strong and effective. Cashiers are encouraged to continue adhering to these procedures to help safeguard cash and reduce the risk of error or fraud.
Operations/Production Department
The objective was to assess whether the reported cash balance was both accurately recorded and adequately safeguarded.

attributes.title: 7. Production Efficiency
attributes.description: It was noted that the production efficiency was 4.66 bags per production worker, and the standard rate achieved was above the set limit. The table below illustrates the findings.
attributes.recommendation: The controls on production workers should be maintained.
attributes.effect: The production efficiency achieved was 4.66, which is above the KPI, implying that production labour was well controlled.

value: We will maintain.
This is recommendable and it shall be maintained.
In the prior audit production efficiency stood at 4.63 bags per production worker.
Previous
An assessment of production efficiency was carried out for the period 1st May 2025 to 3rd June 2025.
The audit revealed that branch effectively and efficiently utilize the labour force.
Operations/Production Department
The aim was to determine if the production workers hired were achieving the set production efficiency of 4.50 bags.

attributes.title: 8. Packing Efficiency Analysis
attributes.description:
The average packing efficiency for the sampled period was 86.23 crates per packer per day, which is below the set target.

The summary of the calculation is presented below
attributes.recommendation: Branch management should ensure packers hired continue to be controlled well and maintain efficiency.
attributes.effect: The packing efficiency achieved was 99.20, which is above the KPI, implying that packing labour was well controlled.

value: We shall continue to ensure this is maintained
This is good, the branch should maintain this.
In prior audit packing efficiency stood at 97.14 crates per slicers.
Previous
Packing Efficiency was computed for a period of 34 days from 1st May 2025 to 3rd June 2025.
Internal audit found that the branch effectively and efficiently utilize labour force.
Operations/Production Department
The aim was to determine whether the set company standard of 97 crates per packer was being achieved.

attributes.title: 9. Vehicles Fuel consumption analysis
attributes.description:
It was noted that most branch vehicles had minimal fuel consumption variances from the set standards except for KCW 288Z& KBZ 649T which had faulty odometer resulting in inaccurate recording of kilometres covered.

The table below illustrates the findings:-
attributes.recommendation: Branch management should strengthen fuel consumption controls to help mitigate potential losses
attributes.effect: Variations in fuel consumption from the standard rates affect cost budgeting and planning.

value:
KCW 288Z had a faulty speed motor, which resulted in an error in the distance covered. The speed motor had be repaired.

We will closely track the fuel consumption of all vehicles and make sure it remains within established standards.
The fuel consumption of all vehicles will be closely monitored to help keep it within the set standards

In prior audit it was noted that KDL 169U - Suba, KCH 511N - Homabay and KTWC 683X - Migosi tuktuk routes were overconsuming while KCV 784R - Kendubay, KCN 827L - Koru and KBZ 483E - Oyugis were saving fuel as per the set rate standards.
Previous
An analysis of fuel consumption was done for the month of May2025.
Fuel controls were not strong enough, and the branch needs to strengthen them to keep fuel consumption within set standards.
Operations/Production Department

The primary objectives were to evaluate compliance with fuel efficiency standards, identify any areas of inefficiency, and recommend strategies for reducing fuel consumption and associated costs. The audit encompassed a comprehensive review of fuel records, maintenance logs, and related policies and procedures.

attributes.title: 10. 	Analysis of Poly bags Damages
attributes.description:
The following were the findings: -

·        A total of 10,227 pieces of poly bags were deducted from the poly bags inventory, reportedly due to damages incurred during packing process.

·      Over the same period, 5,013 pieces were sent to the crushing department, and 2,981 pieces were stock back during stock take, resulting to a variance of 2,233 pieces.

· This variance suggests intentional overstatement of poly bags damages to conceal inventory shortfalls/loss, indicting weakness on control.

·    The percentage of poly bag damage against total production was 1.06%, which is on high side and suggests inefficiencies in material handling.
attributes.recommendation:
The branch should enhance controls around the packing area to minimize poly bag damages. This includes training staff on proper handling.

The operations team should establish an acceptable damage threshold (e.g., a percentage benchmark relative to production) to guide and monitor inventory losses. The absence of such a standard creates room for misuse or abuse at the branch level.
attributes.effect:
The unaccounted variance of 2,233 poly bags between SAP stock-out and physical dispatch indicates a potential loss or misappropriation of company assets and highlights gaps in inventory controls at the branch level.

By overstating poly bags indicate a manipulation of the records intentional to conceal a short fall or theft.

value: We will ensure that poly bags are recorded by the slicer at the end of each shift to improve accuracy and accountability.
The Branch Manager should ensure that the quantity of stock out matches the actual damages.
N/A
Current
An analysis was conducted on poly bag damages for period from 1st May 2025 to 3rd June 2025.
A weakness was noted on poly bags controls and branch needs to tighten the control to mitigate the loss.
Operations/Production Department

The objective of the review was to: -

  1. Assess the accuracy and authenticity of the records of the production poly bags damages

  2. Verify whether the quantity of production damaged poly bags stock-outs matched the quantity physically sent to the crushing department.

  3. Establish the percentage of poly bag damages in relation to actual production over the reviewed period.

attributes.title: 11. Analysis of the Bread returned from Routes
attributes.description:
·         The following were the findings: -

v  A total of 8,167 pieces of bread (converted to 400g pieces) were returned during this period.

v  These returns equate to an estimated revenue loss of Ksh 432,851, based on the mini shop selling price.

v  Of the total returns, 1,596 pieces (19.54%) were attributed to torn wrappers.

v  The remaining 6,571 pieces (80.45%) were linked to production inefficiencies such as overbaking, underbaking, undersized loaves, short expiry, and deformation.

v The estimated revenue loss due to production-related issues amounted to Ksh 348,263, representing 80.45% of the total loss.

v  Family products (800g & 600g) accounted for the highest volume of returns, totaling 4,837 pieces, which is 59.2% of all route returns.

The table below illustrates the findings
attributes.recommendation:
· At the point of collecting returns from customers, the sales crew should inspect and accurately record the reason for each return. During offloading, the branch should utilize the returns summary generated from the SAP system and cross-verify it against physical returns to ensure accuracy and accountability

·      The branch manager should closely monitor bread balances, while the supervisor must verify the sell-by dates of packed bread to prevent short-expiry products from being dispatched to the market.

·      The branch should strengthen its production processes to ensure that only high-quality products are produced. In addition, both the sales crew and customers should be sensitized on proper product handling to minimize returns resulting from mishandling.
attributes.effect: ·      The analysis reveals that most of returns (over 80.45%) stem from production-related deficiencies. These issues such as deformation, under/over baked, short expiry, and under size are largely controllable through improved production practices.

value: We will follow up and ensure that actual returns are properly recorded.

We noted that the previous branch manager was overstating the route balances, and as a result, he was suspended and is currently awaiting disciplinary action. We will ensure that route damages are accurately recorded to reflect the true position.
N/A
An analysis was conducted on all bread returns to the branch between 1st May 2025 to 7th June 2025.
Overstating of the route returns indicate a weakness on controlling bread returns.
Operations/Production Department
The objective was to identify the reasons for the returns and quantify the financial impact. This review excluded returns from the mini shop and supermarket.
